title: Hosting hugo on github
content:
Hugo is a static website generator and github pages are a free way to host webpages Prerequisites:
 Hugo (https://github.com/gohugoio/hugo) A working hugo website  Hosting on github   Create two github repositories:
One will contain the hugo source files and can be named anything you like. I will name it blog.
The second one must be called .github.io and will contain the final files.
  Clone the them to your computer and put them both into one folder.
  Copy your hugo files into the first repository and make sure it works with hugo serve.
  Once ready to deploy, commit your changes. Then use hugo -d ../<username>.github.io to deploy the websites files to the folder. By using this command you will get the files in the format that is needed to host them on github pages.
  cd into the other folder and use git add *, then git commit -m "<message>" and then git push. You will be asked for your password and username.
  Once done you can navigate to .github.io to see the webpage.

title: Animated wallpapers
content:
Creating animated wallpapers from .gif files It can be tricky to do some things in the i3wm windows manager. I have searched for a long time for a way to run gifs as an animated background. It is especially nice when you have a loop of falling rain or koi fish in a pond.
Here is what you will need:
Prerequisites:
 xwinwrap  animated_background.sh
#!/bin/sh  [ -z "$1" ] && exit killall xwinwrap sleep 0.3 xwinwrap -ov -g 1366x768+0+0 -- mpv -wid WID "$1" --no-osc --no-osd-bar --loop-file --player-operation-mode=cplayer --no-audio --panscan=1.0 --no-keepaspect --no-input-default-bindings --hwdec& Make the file executable chmod +x animated_background.sh
To run the script simply run ./animated_background.sh <path-to-gif> from the file location.
